Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Climatic drivers of demography and reproductive behavior of tropical birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Weather has a large impact on where animals are found and how they live. We know a lot about how seasonal patterns of temperature (winter vs. summer) impact the animals around us, but we rarely consider how seasonal patterns of rainfall might impact animals in considerably different ways. Such impacts are especially likely near the equator, where the temperature is always high and seasons can swing dramatically between "wet" and "dry". This project will test how a tropical bird manages to thrive in an area that experiences periods of extremely high rainfall. This type of study is important for helping us understand how changing climate may impact animals, especially in places like the tropics that contain a large number of species that are found nowhere else. Results of this research have the potential to change how we view the role of climate in the lives of tropical organisms.

One of the classic paradigms in tropical ecology is that year-round warmth and humidity frees organisms from climatic stressors and constraints, releasing them from energetic limitations and heightening the importance of biological interactions in shaping life history and behavior. This project is intellectually risky because it challenges this deeply entrenched view. The investigator proposes that precipitation extremes limit fitness and tests the hypothesis that precipitation-fitness relationships are unimodal. The work builds upon more than a decade of studies on a small, tropical, frugivorous, lek-breeding bird -- the White-ruffed Manakin (Corapipo altera) -- in Central American montane forests. The investigator will elucidate responses of manakins to variation in long-term mean precipitation regimes and short-term rainfall events across populations spanning moderately wet to extremely wet forests on both the Pacific and Caribbean slopes of Costa Rica. Mechanistic links will be sought between high rainfall and manakin survival, body condition, and reproduction. Additionally, previously-documented reproductive behavior and lek attributes will be contrasted with data from two new focal populations on the Caribbean slope, testing proposed climatic constraints on sexually-selected behavior at leks. Two PhD students and four undergraduate students will be mentored in research and the team will produce educational materials for use in public schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A common, temperate-zone view of tropical rainforests is that they are climatically benign: warm and wet year conditions round. In the context of this seemingly unstressful environment, studies of the evolution of tropical organisms has usually focused on how other organisms shape evolution of morphology, behavior, and life history (i.e. competitors, predators, food sources, parasites, members of the same species). This research proposed and tested ideas that challenge the dominant paradigm. The amount and timing of rainfall is crucial in shaping the distribution and seasonality of tropical species. Our work tested the idea that it is possible for rainforests to be “too rainy”—that each species has a range of precipitation conditions under which it thrives, and when there is either too little or too much, those individuals or populations suffer reproductive or survival costs. In species such as the small Neotropical birds known as manakins—a group subject to strong sexual selection—we hypothesized that at the wettest end of rainfall gradients, the fewer opportunities there would be for a few males to dominate all reproduction due to increased mortality and reduced social stability. We tested these ideas in multiple ways including via analyses of temporal variation in survival within a population, comparisons of reproductive behavior in populations differing in rainfall, genetic analyses of signatures in the strength of sexual selection across rainfall gradients, and comparisons of the morphologies of multiple manakin species living across broad climatic gradients within the tropics.

Our work has so far resulted in two published papers, two more in review, and five more in preparation. One of these is a review that presents a novel model for predicting and interpreting how and when rain affects animals—particularly endotherms (birds and mammals) in tropical regions. The data papers complement this conceptual contribution. We demonstrated the following; (i) how biotic and abiotic sources of selection both contribute to shaping body size evolution across species of manakins; (ii) the mainly negative and species-specific responses to wet years in demographic analyses of birds living in an extremely wet montane forest of Costa Rica; (iii) shifts in genetic structure among populations of manakins indicative of variation in the relative strength of natural and sexual selection; (iv) differences in the reproductive behavior and social structure of a species of manakin living near the wet and dry ends of their hygric niches; (v) the drivers of inter-individual reproductive behaviors via experimental field methods; and (vi) the biomechanical mechanisms involved in reproductive display.  

We have increased public-access genomic resources (a new genome) that is already being used by other researchers. We have presented the results of this work in four scientific seminars, seven conference presentations, and developed/delivered 16 community engagement products. Two bilingual posters we created that hang at the entrance to Volcán Tenorio national park in Costa Rica reach over 120 thousand visitors annually. The project has contributed to training two graduate students, eleven undergraduates and technicians, involved multiple collaborators from with the USA, from Central America, and from South America. The project has been especially strong at developing the careers of women and Latino scientists.
